comments.commentBody: Those here at the newspaper of record for public employees who  believe "Government is the answer, what is the question?" Are not anything near a majority!

Yes the Republican-led House does have a radical vision. But, contrary to your assertion, they did get there by election.

Obama was elected president, not emperor. The House was duly elected with a Republican majority. it is the President's duty to work with the Congress elected by the people. If he can't fulfill that duty, as has been demonstrated for the past five years, it is more then obvious that Obama is the problem.

The problem is that Americans cast 1.5 million more votes for House Democrats than for House Republicans, but the Republicans still won the majority of the seats -- thanks to both gerrymandering and the geographic concentration of many Democratic voters. Worse than that, in the Senate, where the Republicans are in the minority, they have used the filibuster in unprecedented ways to block normal legislative processes. Bottom line -- the Republicans don't accept the basic principles of abiding by the voters' will anymore.

Republicans have a radical vision. They can't get there by compromise. They can't get there by balance. They failed to get there by elections.

They are still trying to get what they believe in. They are showing they'll do anything for what they believe in.

We've rejected what they believe in. Now we must be rid of them. Otherwise, if this does not work, they'll try something even worse.

What a joy to read Satchit Balsari's comments about his maiden trip to Islamabad! His comments bring hope and cheer for those of us who desperately want India and Pakistan to get along and help lift people in both countries. It is essentially one family that rather than working to heal the wounds of partition has focussed on blaming and undermining each other's humanity for the last 65 years. It is great to hear that saner voices might be rising. It is great that Asia Society organized this exchange. Next time may be an exchange among farmers and small business people of two countries can be tried. We need to build all the bridges we can so that all people can go across both ways.

Interesting article. The bio at the end reveals that the author is an NRI living in New York. I'd be interested to know if Mr. Balsari has interacted with Pakistanis in America. I've heard a few anecdotes suggesting that Indians and Pakistanis living abroad sometimes find common ground more easily than those who live back home.

Dear Concerned Citizen,
And what about students who go to Medical School or seek advanced degrees in Math, Science, or Technology. They have often gone without insurance or taken on extra debt to obtain coverage. Is it fair to these students who will become significant contributors to the country to have to abandon their studies because of health care costs?

That's not true. SS is not independent of the deficit because the SS administration buys US Govt bonds with any funds it has. The US Govt promptly spends the money. It's as if you took all of your life savings and gave the money to your fun loving brother who goes on vacation a lot. He promises to pay you back.

That's what has really happened. It is true. Do you not believe this?

The government budget is absolutely nothing like a personsl budget. Raising the debt ceiling does not raise the debt. These are complex economic concepts.  Recent spending cuts have been significsnt and in keeping with Republican demands. Had George W. Bush not wildly spent on unjustified wars, this country would not be in debt. The Republicans spent a huge chunk of change overseas instead of being fiscally responsible here at home. Read, read, read. Facts matter. If you are not really rich, you shouldn't be listening to the opinions of those who are. Read about Rupert Murdock's (owns FOX) association with the Koch brothers.  You'll be surprised by what they stand for (or maybe you won't).

Dear Oort, you are already paying for other's heath care every time they go to the emergency room. I guess you don't want to be part of society. And no one is asking you to pay for anyone else's retirement.
I think you mean secession.
Yeah, Kay, anyone going to the ER will be treated. And left bankrupt afterward. Hope it happens to you soon.

In the past, these tactics weren't necessary because Presidents didn't refuse to work with the House. Divided governments have often occurred in our history, but we've rarely had a President who not only refused to acknowledge that another party controlled the House, but whose sole interaction with that party was casting them as villains and obstructionists.

Obama's response to divided government has been, rather than work with Republicans on actually accomplishing anything, to subvert Congress and complain bitterly to the American people that without complete control of both houses of Congress, he simply cannot be expected to do anything. Obviously actually working with the opposition, a grand tradition in American politics, is beneath him, just as the realm of policy is beneath him. He's a President who can win elections, but accomplish nothing else.

No, I want a president that listens to the people....over 60% of the population were against the ACA prior to it becoming law. Obama pushed this legislation through and expected the polls of public support to change over time after the fact..and they have.  I expect this is the same tactic being used by the Republicans/TPs so I ask you....is this the system you want?

I have one simple question for anyone on the right who supports the tactics of the their representatives in the House:  do you want this to become the new way our government is run?  Should the party that controls the House really control the government?  Because if the Dems agree to this blackmail, that is what will happen for every future funding bill and debt increase.  Republicans AND Democrats will use this strategy because it worked.  And someday, probably in the not so distant future, a Democratically controlled house will blackmail a Republican Senate and President into destroying legislation they passed, that was supported by a majority of the country.  Is that really what you want?

libertyfirst76:
huh? maybe a visit to California would help!
Look up what?  That people who couldn't get health care need it, instead of being forced to go to the emergency room so that the rest so us have to pay for it?  Go troll somewhere else.
Who forced anything? The ACA was passed by both chambers of Congress, signed by the president, and upheld as constitutional by the Supreme  Court. That's how our system works.
Spending on what "they" want is always ok.  How nice that they forget about their trillion dollar wars.  How about we spend  money on US?   Oh, of course, not enough money for the 1 %.

Really?

Asking the House to vote?
Telling us the projected realities on 10/17?

More of a leader than you probably can imagine.

I'm not a big fan of the ACA, but your picture of a president who on the one hand conspires to make a law a certain way but on the other hand leaves it for others to make is pretty incoherent and even self-contradictory; this really damages the credibility of everything you say.

For all those insisting that the Affordable Care Act was implemented rather than a single payer system in order to please Republicans, this is completely erroneous. The ACA, the signature issue of Obama's Presidency, became his pet issue because he wanted to outpoint Clinton on her own area of expertise during his campaign. Remember his campaign promise that the salient difference between his health care plan and that of Clinton was that his would not feature an individual mandate? Strange that a Presidency based upon lies and deceit has led us to this point.

As to the ACA itself, Obama pursued the private insurance option not to garner Republican votes, which should be obvious given that no Republicans were involved in the crafting of the ACA, but to assuage the concerns of centrists happy with their current health care options. Otherwise stated, in typical Obama fashion, he gave up on what was considered the superior policy initiative, despite having the votes to pass it, because he cared more about the politics, just as he always has.

Furthermore, Obama's leadership capability and policy making skills were on full display during the formation of the Affordable Care Act. That is to say, he contributed absolutely nothing to the discussion and left the legislation for Congress to draft, as fits such a shallow, vacuous Presidency.

And now Obama refuses to lead with the country on the verge of default, solely because he considers it good politics. Hardly surprising.

Republicans used a combination of gerrymandering and fear-mongering to get more districts to vote for Republican candidates in the House. As for negotiations, the Republicans could care less about negotiating if they can't repeal the ACA, which they won't. They could have negotiated other items at any time but this was their last-ditch, desperate plan all along. They are just sore losers who can't stand the idea of a black president successfully passing a universal health care law that was originally proposed by a Republican - Teddy Roosevelt -  in 1900. Except in those days, it was the Democrats who represented the interests of the South, which has always been in opposition to the federal government.
President Obama a thug?  I stopped reading there.

Isn't pretty much everyone paid by other people's money? You work but it's not your money till your boss signs your paycheck.Seams to me most everyone is getting and using other peoples money for most everything. Circulating money around makes the economy work. Hoarding money on a large scale has no impact other than removing some circulation money. And that's an impact anyway.

The issue today is too much money is going to the very top before it circulates through the economy. Rather than after. And even then it's still too much going to the top.

And fewer people at the top still get way more in dollars of other peoples money than the small trickle down we've seen now for 30 yrs. More than is spent on SNAP and other assistance programs for the poorer folk goes to the wealthiest in all sorts of forms.

Many times in the past the government has dealt with depressions. And they created jobs - the CCC is one of the best known when inflation rates were high and people had no jobs. A similar approach could be taken today but that's just plain old socialism to the gop mindset.

Where are all Boehners JOBS, JOBS, JOBS that was their main campaign focus in 2010? Nada, zippo, zilch. Although Mr. Obama did give them some proposals but we know if it's not the gop idea of the week nothing will happen. JOBS JOBS JOBS that's all I heard from them before. Now I know they meant Jobs in China.

Other people's money huh? How about, all that money got "made" by other people's time, creativity, hard work and labor.

Sigh.

Some people really don't get the fact that all things are connected. There is no such thing as "my" money any more than I own the air.

This problem began with the incredibly simplistic ideas associated with supply side, trickle down economics. No matter how rich the rich get they cannot spend enough to generate the kind of demand that keeps a capitalist society healthy. Living wages, affordable health and child care, and sound fiscal and monetary policies, will do more to ensure both individual and corporate prosperity than the discredited (after years of implementation) policies the GOP keeps promulgating.

Simple question:

Did Henry Ford, Bill Gates, Steve Jobs, etc., do better things by making their money than they would by giving it away?

I think the "making" of the money did more better things for more people than the giving away part.

That's the philosophy of capitalism. It comes with some hiccups -- granted -- sometimes people suffer. But, ultimately, they are better off with competition than they are with insincere beneficence.

That's what we're talking about here -- whether Obamacare and the continuation of the Great Society imagined by Franklin Roosevelt makes sense.

I think not.

That is what this dispute is really about. We're about evenly split on it -- I think because about 50% of the people are getting money from the Gov't, and that's a powerful influence.

It would be nice to see how these people felt if they were not getting paid with other people's money.

To liberty: every penny of that $17T was authorized by those 'ax and spenders' in Congress. And 'credit line' is not what this is about. You really don't understand government finance. HInt: it's not at all like household finance. The 'survival of our Constitutional Republic' is at risk when we no longer have majority rule. No majority rule is what the House republicans want. Your comments are ridiculous.
Are you better off defaulting on your credit cards?
While they're at it, how about a prorated paycut for both Congress and the President for every day the government was shutdown.
Taxation without representation! :(
Truly, they do not want to work.  Their happy with the vacation and back pay.
The demand that hasn't been earned that liberty76 is talking about must be the respect that the Representative from Indiana was talking about.

BillyDKidd, remember in the last House election that more people voted for Democrats than Republicans? And that the only reason there is a a Republican "majority" in the House is because of gerrymandering? My own district in NC looks like a scythe.

Maybe there's something to that, then.
